Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: 3D Capturing Technology Based on Light Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will help satisfy the growing demand in 3D capturing technology primarily caused by the need for photorealistic content for 3D applications, and better computer vision solutions for autonomous machinery. Additionally, for researchers and conservationists, 3D capturing is a way to preserve precious artifacts and study them without endangering of permanently losing them during transportation or due to natural deterioration. For retailers and designers, low cost accurate 3D representations of products are needed for virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) applications that open new possibilities to connect with their customers. Finally, as display makers continue to improve upon light field (LF) displays, LF image and video will potentially become mainstream and a pipeline will need to exist to capture, compress, and stream this new form of media.

This I-Corps project utilizes a specialized computer numerical control camera and compression algorithms to record multiple photos of an object or a scene and based on this raw data to construct light field (LF) images which preserve the complex interactions between the lights and the surfaces in the scene. This project develops compression and reconstruction algorithms that exploit the redundant information found in LF images while also allowing quick decompression on viewing devices (applicable for web, virtual reality (VR), and augmented reality (AR)). The 3D content (object or scene) can then be viewed with six degrees of freedom and in stereovision. This provides a complete solution to capture a generic object regardless of shape and material in a portable 3D format without manual post-editing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project focused on customer discovery and market research for a new 3D capturing technology based on light fields. The technology has the potential to satisfy the growing demand for photorealistic 3D content of inventory and specimens for visualization on web, virtual, and augmented reality applications.


During the program the team identified go-to-market strategy, including customer segments, market size, and the value proposition for the proposed innovation. It was determined that the 3D content creation market accounts for $2.8B in 2018 with 18% increase each year with more retailers adopting 3D visualization on web and for augmented and virtual reality applications. The initial customer segment mainly consists of three kinds of professionals. First, content directors of production studios working with furniture. Second, home goods retailers willing to 3D digitize their inventory. Third, in-house content teams of big name retailers. 


The team identified the customer necessity of finding a solution for capturing objects with certain materials (e.g., with fur, mirrors, crystals, high specularity, subsurface scattering) that currently cannot be modelled with high quality and cannot be captured with available technologies in format suitable for viewing. The current process is manual and requires the skills of a 3D artist to model the inventory. In some cases, laser and structured light scanners are used, but the quality of capturing certain materials, the required processing time, and the size of the output file make this approach impractical in most cases. 
The team also designed and built a prototype to test technical ideas and develop a proof of concept. It included a specialized computer numerical control camera and a software application for processing and viewing captured light fields.
